    Data Inventory Table

    Kyle Baron

    2020-07-22

    data-inventory.Rmd

    The data inventory table counts subjects and observations in your data set. It will also tally missing or BQL observations.

    Basic table by study

    library(pmtables)
library(dplyr)

all <- pmtables:::data("obs")
pk <- filter(all, SEQ==1)

    A summary of PK data by study

    pt_data_inventory(pk, by = vars(Study = STUDYf))
. $data
. # A tibble: 5 x 7
.   STUDYf   Number.SUBJ Number.MISS Number.OBS Number.BQL Percent.OBS Percent.BQL
.   <chr>          <int>       <int>      <int>      <int> <chr>       <chr>      
. 1 "12-DEM…          30           8        427         15 13.9        0.5        
. 2 "12-DEM…          50          10       1152         38 37.4        1.2        
. 3 "11-DEM…          40          10        920         30 29.9        1.0        
. 4 "13-DEM…          40           7        582         11 18.9        0.4        
. 5 "\\hlin…         160          35       3081         94 100.0       3.1        
.

    Paneled summary

    We can also panel this summary by another covariate

    pt_data_inventory(
  pk, 
  by = vars(Study = STUDYf), 
  panel = vars("Renal function" = RFf)
)
. $data
. # A tibble: 8 x 10
.   STUDYf RFf   Number.SUBJ Number.MISS Number.OBS Number.BQL `Group percent.…
.   <chr>  <chr>       <int>       <int>      <int>      <int> <chr>           
. 1 "12-D… norm…          30           8        427         15 17.9            
. 2 "12-D… norm…          50          10       1152         38 48.2            
. 3 "11-D… norm…          10           3        229          8 9.6             
. 4 "13-D… norm…          40           7        582         11 24.4            
. 5 "11-D… mild           10           4        228          8 100.0           
. 6 "11-D… mode…          10           1        232          7 100.0           
. 7 "11-D… seve…          10           2        231          7 100.0           
. 8 "\\hl… seve…         160          35       3081         94 ---             
. # … with 3 more variables: `Group percent.BQL` <chr>, `Overall
. #   percent.OBS` <chr>, `Overall percent.BQL` <chr>

    Stacked summary

    Use this when you want to have a single table that summarizes different endpoints. This is a paneled summary where each panel is a summary only of what is in that panel.

    pt_data_inventory(
  all, 
  panel = vars(Endpoint = SEQf), 
  by = vars("Study" = STUDYf), 
  stacked = TRUE
)
. $data
. # A tibble: 11 x 8
.    STUDYf SEQf  Number.SUBJ Number.MISS Number.OBS Number.BQL Percent.OBS
.    <chr>  <chr>       <int>       <int>      <int>      <int> <chr>      
.  1 "12-D… DEMO…          30           8        427         15 13.9       
.  2 "12-D… DEMO…          50          10       1152         38 37.4       
.  3 "11-D… DEMO…          40          10        920         30 29.9       
.  4 "13-D… DEMO…          40           7        582         11 18.9       
.  5 "\\hl… DEMO…         160          35       3081         94 100.0      
.  6 "11-D… ESTR…          40           0         40          0 50.6       
.  7 "13-D… ESTR…          40           1         39          0 49.4       
.  8 "\\hl… ESTR…          80           1         79          0 100.0      
.  9 "11-D… BMD            40           9        111          0 49.1       
. 10 "13-D… BMD            40           5        115          0 50.9       
. 11 "\\hl… BMD            80          14        226          0 100.0      
. # … with 1 more variable: Percent.BQL <chr>
.
